Explanation: Whatever the quadrilateral when we are drawing it in isometric views the base will make 30 degrees and other sides will tend to show up like we are watching from some particular point as in perspective view in 1 dimension.

Question: Lines of sights (projectors) for oblique projection will be ______________
Options: a) Parallel to each other and perpendicular to projection plane
b) Not parallel to each other and perpendicular to projection plane
c) Parallel to each other and inclined to projection plane
d) Not parallel to each other and inclined to projection plane
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: The oblique projection represents three dimensional objects on the projection plane by one view only. This type of drawing is useful for making an assembly of an object and provides directly a production drawing of the object for manufacturing purpose.

Question: Which of the following statement is wrong in case of oblique projection?
Options: a) The object is drawn with the reduced dimensions
b) Projectors are parallel to each other and inclined to projection plane
c) The choice of the position of the object depends upon the shape and size
d) The faces of object which are perpendicular to the plane of projection will be distorted
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: When an observer looks towards an object from infinity, the lines of sight will be parallel to each other and inclined to the projection plane in oblique projection, but the lines of sight will be parallel to each other and perpendicular to projection plane in orthographic projection.

Question: When the receding lines are drawn to full size scale then the oblique projection is ___________
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: In oblique projection the faces of object which are perpendicular to the plane of projection will be distorted and all the faces of the object are distorted in the shape and size in isometric projection.

Question: When the receding lines are drawn to half size scale then the oblique projection is __________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In isometric projection the object is drawn with the reduced dimensions for about 82% but in oblique projection the object is drawn with the actual dimensions. The choice of the position of the object depends upon the shape and size.

Question: Which are not usually used as angle between the projection plane and receding lines for oblique projection?
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: When the receding lines are drawn to half size scale then the oblique projection is cabinet projection. When the receding lines are drawn to full size scale then the oblique projection is cavalier projection.

Question: The appearance of the distortion of an object can be improved by ___________ the length of the receding lines.
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: When the receding lines are drawn to half size scale then the oblique projection is cabinet projection. When the receding lines are drawn to full size scale then the oblique projection is cavalier projection.

Question: In oblique projection, the object is assumed to be placed with one face _______________
Options: a) parallel to plane of projection
c) perpendicular to plane of projection
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Usually used as angles are 30, 45, 60 degrees which are between the projection plane and receding lines for oblique projection. But if needed any angle can be taken as per requirement of the view.

Question: The perpendicular edges of planes parallel to projection plane are drawn at an angle of 30, 45, 60 degrees with the horizontal. The inclined lines are called _____________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The appearance of the distortion of an object can be improved by shortening the length of the receding lines. The receding lines may be inclined either upwards or downwards, or to the left or right depending upon the necessity to show the details.

Question: The faces parallel to projection plane are having ________ size and shape in oblique projection.
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In oblique projection, the object is assumed to be placed with one face parallel to plane of projection and receding lines are drawn from the faces parallel to projection plane and other parallel face.

Question: In cavalier projection the receding lines are drawn _________
Options: a) half of its actual size
b) double of its actual size
d) increased or decreased to a particular ratio
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: Projectors are the imaginary lines drawn from object to projection planes. Slanting edges can be used for edges of pyramid etc. The perpendicular edges of planes parallel to projection plane are drawn at an angle of 30, 45, 60 degrees with the horizontal. The inclined lines are called receding lines.

Question: In perspective projection, the eye is assumed to be situated at a _______ position relative to the object. The ______ is placed between ____ and the _________
Options: a) definite, picture plane, eye, object
b) indefinite, object, eye, picture plane
c) indefinite, picture plane, eye, object
d) indefinite, object, picture plane, eye
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In perspective projection, the eye is assumed to be situated at a definite position relative to the object. The picture plane is placed between eye and the object and the object can also placed between the eye and picture plane.

Question: In perspective projection the projectors are _________ to each other and ________ to picture plane.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: In perspective projection, the projectors are not parallel to each other and inclined to picture plane. In orthographic view the projector are parallel to each other and perpendicular to plane of projection.

Question: In perspective projection, the horizontal plane in which the object is assumed to be situated is called ______________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: In perspective projection, the horizontal plane in which the object is assumed to be situated is called ground plane. And the imaginary plane is at the level of the eye above the ground plane and at right angles to the picture plane is called the horizontal plane.

Question: In perspective projection, the point where the eye of the observer is located while viewing the object is called ____________
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: In perspective projection, the point where the eye of the observer is located while viewing the object is called station point and the distance of the station point from the picture plane, when taken equal to about twice the greatest dimension of the object gives the good view in the perspective.

Question: In perspective projection, the point in which the perpendicular axis pierces the picture plane and lies on horizon line is called _____________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: In perspective projection, the point in which the perpendicular axis pierces the picture plane and lies on horizon line is called center of vision. And the line in which the horizon plane intersects the picture plane is called horizon line. It is parallel to ground line.

Question: In perspective projection, the imaginary plane is at the level of the eye above the ground plane and at right angles to the picture plane is called ______________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In perspective projection, the imaginary plane is at the level of the eye above the ground plane and at right angles to the picture plane is called the horizontal plane. And the horizontal plane in which the object is assumed to be situated is called ground plane.

Question: In perspective projection, the imaginary vertical plane which passes through the station point and the center of vision. It contains the perpendicular axis. It is perpendicular to both the picture plane and ground plane. It is called ____________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In perspective projection, the imaginary vertical plane which passes through the station point and the center of vision. It contains the perpendicular axis. It is perpendicular to both the picture plane and ground plane. It is called central plane.

Question: In perspective projection, the line drawn through the station point and perpendicular to the picture plane is sometimes called the line of sight or axis of vision is called _________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: In perspective projection, the line drawn through the station point and perpendicular to the picture plane is sometimes called the line of sight or axis of vision is called perpendicular line.

Question: In perspective projection, the horizontal plane placed above the horizon plane on which the top view of the object and of the perspective elements is projected is called ____________
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: In perspective projection, the horizontal plane placed above the horizon plane on which the top view of the object and of the perspective elements is projected is called auxiliary ground plane.

Question: In which method, points on the perspective are obtained by projecting the top view and either the front view or the side view of visual rays?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: In visual-ray method, points on the perspective are obtained by projecting the top view and either the front view or the side view of visual rays. In addition to the top view of the visual rays, use of vanishing points of straight lines is made in Vanishing point method.

Question: In addition to the top view of the visual rays, use of vanishing points of straight lines is made in this method. What is this method?
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: In a visual-ray method, points on the perspective are obtained by projecting the top view and either the front view or the side view of visual rays. In addition to the top view of the visual rays, use of vanishing points of straight lines is made in Vanishing point method.

Question: In perspective projection, the line in which the horizon plane intersects the picture plane is called ______________ and it is parallel to ground line.
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: In perspective projection, the line in which the horizon plane intersects the picture plane is called horizon line. It is parallel to ground line. And the point in which the perpendicular axis pierces the picture plane and lies on horizon line is called center of vision.

Question: When an object has its one or more faces parallel to the picture plane, its perspective is called ___________ perspective also called one point perspective.
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: When an object has its one or more faces parallel to the picture plane, its perspective is called parallel perspective also called one point perspective as the edges converge to a single vanishing point of the parallel faces.

Question: When an object has its two faces inclined to the picture plane, its perspective is called _________ perspective also called two point perspectives.
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: When an object has its two faces inclined to the picture plane, its perspective is called angular perspective also called two point perspectives as the edges of the object converge to two vanishing points.

Question: When an object has its three faces inclined to the picture plane, its perspective is called _________ perspective also called 3 point perspective.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: When an object has its three faces inclined to the picture plane, its perspective is called oblique perspective also called 3 point perspective as edges of the object converge to three vanishing points.

Question: Vanishing points for all horizontal lines are inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane are given special name of _________ points.
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Vanishing points for all horizontal lines are inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane are given special name of distance points on account of their definite positions. They are equidistant from the center of vision.

Question: Which are equidistant from the center of vision?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The distance points are equidistant from the center of vision the distance of each from the centre of vision being equal to the distance of the station point from the picture plane the perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane converge to a distance points on the horizon line.

Question: The distance of which points from the centre of vision being equal to the distance of the station point from the picture plane?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The distance points are equidistant from the center of vision the distance of each from the centre of vision being equal to the distance of the station point from the picture plane the perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane converge to a distance points on the horizon line.

Question: The perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at ___ degrees to the picture plane converge to a distance points on the horizon line.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: The distance points are equidistant from the center of vision the distance of each from the centre of vision being equal to the distance of the station point from the picture plane the perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane converge to a distance points on the horizon line.

Question: The perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane converge to a distance points on the _______________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The distance points are equidistant from the center of vision the distance of each from the centre of vision being equal to the distance of the station point from the picture plane the perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane converge to a distance points on the horizon line.

Question: The perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane converge to a ________ points on the horizon line.
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The distance points are equidistant from the center of vision the distance of each from the centre of vision being equal to the distance of the station point from the picture plane the perspectives of all horizontal lines inclined at 45 degrees to the picture plane converge to a distance points on the horizon line.

Question: The measuring line or the line of heights is the trace or the line of intersection with the _________ plane, of the vertical plane containing the point or points whose heights are to be determined.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: The measuring line or the line of heights is the trace or the line of intersection with the picture plane, of the vertical plane containing the point or points whose heights are to be determined. Heights of points lying in the different vertical plane can be measured from their respective line of heights.

Question: Heights of points lying in different ___________ can be measured from their respective line of heights.
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The measuring line or the line of heights is the trace or the line of intersection with the picture plane, of the vertical plane containing the point or points whose heights are to be determined. Heights of points lying in different vertical plane can be measured from their respective line of heights.

Question: The measuring line or the line of heights is the trace or the line of intersection with the picture plane, of the ____________ plane containing the point or points whose heights are to be determined.
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The measuring line or the line of heights is the trace or the line of intersection with the picture plane, of the vertical plane containing the point or points whose heights are to be determined.

Question: The perspective view of a circle in any type of typical position be_________
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: The station point in anywhere from the picture plane if a circle is placed in any angle with the ground plane in the maximum possible critical position the perspective of the circle will always be an ellipse.

Question: To draw the perspective view of a circle the circle should be enclosed in _______ and then pointing points and next steps goes on.
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: To obtain points on an ellipse, the circle should be enclosed in a square and mid points of sides and intersection of diagonals with the circle are 8 points. Lines are drawn through these points, parallel to the sides of the square.

Question: The perspectives of concentric circles are not concentric __________
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Perspectives of concentric circles are not concentric ellipses. Though the both circles give ellipses but inner ellipse might be closer to one of side of outer ellipse and also might be closer to only one side of outer ellipse.

Question: Curve of any shape can be drawn in perspective by enclosing it in a ___________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In orthographic projection, isometric projection the parallel faces in the solid which having same dimensions will show true exact sizes or in proportions and also in parallel faces but in perspective view the parallel line, edges, faces show differ in dimensions.

Question: For large objects such as buildings, the station point is usually taken at the eye level of a person of normal height that is about _____ meters.
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In orthographic projection, isometric projection the parallel faces in the solid which having same dimensions will show true exact sizes or in proportions and also in parallel faces but in perspective view the parallel line, edges, faces show differ in dimensions.

Question: The perspective will show the object _________ in size when it is placed behind the picture plane. If the object is moved nearer the picture plane the size of the perspective will ___________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Curve of any shape can be drawn in perspective by enclosing it in a rectangle and then drawing horizontal and vertical lines through a number of points on the curve similar to a circle which is enclosed in square.

Question: The perspective will show the object _________ in size when it is placed in front of the picture plane. If the object is moved nearer the picture plane the size of the perspective will ___________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: In orthographic projection, isometric projection the parallel faces in the solid which having same dimensions will show true exact sizes or in proportions and also in parallel faces but in perspective view the parallel line, edges, faces show differ in dimensions.

Question: Which of the following is not the definition of center of gravity?
Options: a) A point on which whole weight if body balances
b) A point through which the resultant of forces of gravity of every particle in body acts
c) It is also called center of mass
d) The point in the body where the gravity becomes zero
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: The center of gravity is defined as point on which whole weight if body balances (or) a point through which the resultant of forces of gravity of every particle in the body acts. It is also called center of mass. It may not necessarily lie within the body.

Question: The center of gravity of a triangle is on ______
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: The center of gravity is defined as point on which whole weight if body balances (or) a point through which the resultant of forces of gravity of every particle in body acts. For planar objects like triangle the center of gravity will be at its centroid.

Question: The center of gravity of a circular ring will be a ______________
Options: a) line which acts as axis of that ring
b) point anywhere in its inner circumference
c) point at center of ring
d) point on centroid of cross section of ring
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Given is irregular quadrilateral so first we have to make it to regular simpler shapes like triangle and the finding center of gravity for those and intersection of forces acting gives the center of gravity of whole.

Question: The center of gravity of a right angled triangle having h as height and b as base length and vertex at 90 degrees is at origin.
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Given is trapezium and the steps given are for finding the center of gravity in simple way. In this the parallel lines are extended up to the length of their opposite sides and intersection of line joining ends and line joining midpoints of parallel lines gives the center of gravity.

Question: Which of the following game make use of center of gravity?
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: For equilateral triangle the centroid and circum center and in center coincides so as the centre of gravity is the centroid for any triangle but here comes center of gravity also coincides with all other 3 points.

Question: The center of gravity of a rectangle having h as height and w as width, one of its vertex is origin and its width is along x-axis is _____________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The center of gravity is defined as point on which whole weight if body balances (or) a point through which the resultant of forces of gravity of every particle in body acts. It is also called center of mass. It may not necessarily lie within the body.

Question: Unit for moment of inertia is _____________
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: The moment of inertia is sum of products of areas and squares of perpendicular distances from center of gravity. Since here we are considering the planar objects the area will have unit of m2 and square of distance gives another m2 product is m4.

Question: Moment of inertia of circle about the axis which is passing through its center and perpendicular to that circle is _____________
Answer: Answer: a Explanation: The moment of inertia is sum of products of areas and squares of perpendicular distances from center of gravity. And this gives the moment of inertia of any planar section.

Question: Moment of inertia of a rectangle whose base is b and height is h and axis is along base is __________
Answer: Answer: a Explanation: The moment of inertia is sum of products of areas and squares of perpendicular distances from center of gravity. And this gives the moment of inertia of any planar section.

Question: Moment of inertia of a rectangle whose base is b and height is h and axis is alongside of height is ________
Answer: Answer: b Explanation: The moment of inertia is sum of products of areas and squares of perpendicular distances from center of gravity. And this gives the moment of inertia of any planar section.

Question: Moment of inertia of a triangle having base as b and height as h and axis is along the centroid and parallel the base.
Answer: Answer: c Explanation: The moment of inertia is sum of products of areas and squares of perpendicular distances from center of gravity. And this gives the moment of inertia of any planar section.

Question: Moment of inertia of a triangle having base as b and height as h and axis is along the centroid and parallel the height.
Answer: Answer: b Explanation: The moment of inertia is sum of products of areas and squares of perpendicular distances from center of gravity. And this gives the moment of inertia of any planar section.

Question: A rectangle is having base b and height h. The ratio of the moment of inertia when axis is passing through its base to moment of inertia of when axis passing through center of gravity and parallel to base is ___________
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Moment of inertia of triangle having base b and height h when axis passing through the center of gravity is bh3/12 and moment of inertia when axis passing through base is bh3/3 and ratio is asked it gives 4.

Question: A triangle is having base b and height h. The ratio of the moment of inertia when axis is passing through its base to moment of inertia of when axis passing through centroid and parallel to base is ______
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Moment of inertia of triangle having base b and height h when axis passing through the centroid is bh3/36 and moment of inertia when axis passing through base is bh3/12 and ratio is asked it gives 3.

Question: The moment of inertia is minimum when the axis is  _________
Options: a) passing through center of object
d) passing through centroid of object
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: The moment of inertia is minimum when the axis is passing through the centroid because the moment of inertia is sum of products of areas and squares of perpendicular distances from center of gravity.

Question: In the polar moment of inertia the axis is perpendicular to _____________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Polar moment of inertia is the sum of the moment of inertias of objects when axes are in same plane which are perpendicular to each other let us say x, y axis and polar moment of inertia is about z axis.

Question: Flank is a __________
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: The surface between the crest and the root is called the flank of the thread. Depth is the distance between the crest and root, measured at right angles to the axis. It is equal to the half of the difference between the outside and core diameter denoted by D.

Question: For a unified triangular external thread the distance between the crest and root (d) is ____ when pitch (p) is given.
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: For a buttress thread the distance between the crest and root (d) is 0.75 times the pitch, for square thread ‘d’ is 0.5 times the pitch, for a Whitworth external thread ‘d’ is 0.64 times the pitch, for a unified triangular external thread the ‘d’ is 0.61 times the pitch.

Question: For a Whitworth external thread the distance between the crest and root (d) is ____ when pitch (p) is given.
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: For a buttress thread the distance between the crest and root (d) is 0.75 times the pitch, for square thread ‘d’ is 0.5 times the pitch, for a Whitworth external thread ‘d’ is 0.64 times the pitch.

Question: For buttress thread, the angle between the two flanks is ____
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: For buttress thread the angle between the two flanks is 45 degrees, for British association thread the angle between the two flanks is 47.5 degrees, for acme thread the angle between the two flanks is 29 degrees.

Question: For acme thread, the angle between the two flanks is ____
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: For Whitworth thread the angle between the two flanks is 55 degrees, for British association thread the angle between the two flanks is 47.5 degrees, for acme thread the angle between the two flanks is 29 degrees.

Question: For a square thread, the distance between the crest and root (d) is ____ when pitch (p) is given.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: For a buttress thread the distance between the crest and root (d) is 0.75 times the pitch, for square thread ‘d’ is 0.5 times the pitch, for a Whitworth external thread ‘d’ is 0.64 times the pitch.

Question: For a buttress thread, the distance between the crest and root (d) is ____ when pitch (p) is given.
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: For a buttress thread the distance between the crest and root (d) is 0.75 times the pitch, for square thread ‘d’ is 0.5 times the pitch, for a Whitworth external thread ‘d’ is 0.64 times the pitch.

Question: For Whitworth thread, the angle between the two flanks is ____
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: For Whitworth thread, the angle between the two flanks is 55 degrees, for British association thread the angle between the two flanks is 47.5 degrees, for acme thread the angle between the two flanks is 29 degrees.

Question: For British association thread, the angle between the two flanks is ____
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: For Whitworth thread, the angle between the two flanks is 55 degrees, for British association thread the angle between the two flanks is 47.5 degrees, for acme thread the angle between the two flanks is 29 degrees.

Question: The angle of chamfer for hexagonal and square nut is ____ degrees as per standards.
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: The upper corners of this nut are rounded-off or chamfered. The chamfering is generally conical. The angle of chamfer is 30-45 degrees with the base of the nut. Due to chamfering, an arc is formed on each vertical face and circle is formed on top surface.

Question: The angle through which the spanner will have to be turned to get next hold is ____ degrees in case of hexagonal shape.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: The angle through which the spanner will have to be turned to get next hold is 60 degrees in case of hexagonal shape as 360/6 is 60 degrees. In case of square nut the spanner can have better hold but the angle is 90 degrees so it is more convenient to use hexagonal nut.

Question: Width across the flats in case of hexagonal nut is___ where D is the diameter of the shank.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Width across the flats in case of hexagonal nut is 1.5D+3mm where D is the diameter of shank, thickness or height of nut is D itself and distance across diagonally opposite corners in case of hexagonal nut is 2D.

Question: Distance across diagonally opposite corners in case of hexagonal nut is ______ where D is nominal diameter.
Answer:
Answer:  a
Explanation: Width across the flats in case of hexagonal nut is 1.5D+3mm where D is the diameter of shank, thickness or height of nut is D itself and distance across diagonally opposite corners in case of hexagonal nut is 2D.

Question: What is the name of the nut which is a hexagonal nut with a washer?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Flanged nut is hexagonal nut with a washer that is a flat circular disc attached to it. It is thus provided with a larger bearing surface. A bolt can be used in a comparatively large-size hole with help of this nut. It is widely used in automobiles.

Question: What is the name of the nut which is a hexagonal nut provided with a cylindrical cap?
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: Cap nut is a hexagonal nut provided with a cylindrical cap at the top to protect the end of the bolt from corrosion. It also prevents leakage through the threads. Flanged nut is hexagonal nut with a washer that is a flat circular disc attached to it.

Question: What is the name of the nut which is a cap nut with spherical dome at the top?
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: It is a form of cap nut with spherical dome at top. Flanged nut is hexagonal nut with a washer that is a flat circular disc attached to it. Cap nut is a hexagonal nut provided with a cylindrical cap at the top.

Question: What is the name of the nut which can be easily operated by the thumb and a finger?
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Wing nut can be easily operated by the thumb and a finger and is used where it is required to be adjusted frequently. It is used in a hacksaw. Cap nut is a hexagonal nut provided with a cylindrical cap at the top.

Question: What is the name of the nut which is in form of a ring provided with slots in the curved surface for c-spanner?
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Ring nut is in form of a ring provided with slots in the curved surface for a special C-spanner. These nuts are generally used in pairs, one nut acting as a lock-nut for the other. Wing nut can be easily operated by the thumb and a finger.

Question: What is the outer diameter of washer when a nominal diameter of bolt is 5 mm?
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: When nominal diameter of bolt is D the thickness of the washer is 0.12D and outer diameter is 2D+3 mm and inner diameter is D+0.5mm. Here D is 5 mm so 2D+3 mm = 2 x 5+3= 10+3 = 13 mm.

Question: What is the thickness of washer when a nominal diameter of bolt is D?
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Washer is a cylindrical piece of metal placed below the nut to provide smooth bearing surface. The thickness of washer when nominal diameter of the bolt is D is 0.12D and outer diameter is 2D+3 mm and inner diameter is D+0.5mm.

Question: Which of the following is not reason for arranging locking nuts?
Options: a) to get rid of slack while vibrations in machines
b) to get rid from the loosing of connected parts
c) for more protection and security
d) to get rid of screwing off the bolts
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: There is always a tendency for the nuts to get slack and to screw off the bolts slightly. The connected parts might get loose, and lead to a serious breakdown. It is, therefore, desirable to secure the nut in some way so as to prevent it from getting loose.

Question: Lock-nut or check-nut is chamfered on ___________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The lock nut is used along with an ordinary nut. The thread in lock nut presses against the bottom side of the thread in the bolt. When ordinary nut is held by spanner, while the lock is turned backwards with another spanner the two nuts are thus locked tightly against each other.

Question: The diameter of the hole in which the split pin is to be put is __________ when D is the diameter of bolt.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: When D is the diameter of bolt the diameter of the hole in which the split pin is 0.2D approximately, 0.3D is the height of slot made in the nut in which split pin is arranged and 0.12D is the thickness of the washer.

Question: A hexagonal nut with a slot cut half way across it and a cap screw is passed through clear hole in the upper to lower part. The name of the nut is __________
Options: d) Sawn nut or wiles nut
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: Sawn nut is a hexagonal nut with a slot cut half way across it and a cap screw is passed through clear hole in the upper to lower part. On tightening the screw, the friction between the thread in upper part increases and prevents slacking.

Question: _______________________ is a nut in which a collar is provided at the upper end of the hexagonal nut and a fiber ring is fitted inside it.
Options: d) Sawn nut or wiles nut
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Simmond’s locknut is a nut in which a collar is provided at the upper end of the hexagonal nut and a fiber ring is fitted inside it. The internal diameter of ring is less than the core diameter of the bolt the end of the bolt, on reaching the ring, cuts its own thread in ring which prevents slacking.

Question: _______________ is a nut in which slots are cut in a cylindrical collar provided on the top of the nut, thus overcoming the disadvantage of slotted nut.
Options: d) Sawn nut or wiles nut
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Castle nut is a nut in which slots are cut in a cylindrical collar provided on the top of the nut, thus overcoming the disadvantage of slotted nut the nuts which are widely used in automobile and locomotive engines and also in steam engine.

Question: A hexagonal nut with slots cut in the upper end of it and through opposite faces in which slotted pin is inserted is called _________ nut.
Options: d) Sawn nut or wiles nut
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Slotted nut is a hexagonal nut with slots cut in the upper end of it and through opposite faces in which slotted pin is inserted through the slot which comes in line with the hole drilled in the bolt and is then opened out at its end.

Question: The nut which has a cylindrical grooved collar at its lower end and this collar fits into a corresponding recess in the adjoining piece is named as.
Options: d) Sawn nut or wiles nut
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Grooved nut is a nut which has a cylindrical grooved collar at its lower end and this collar fits into a corresponding recess in the adjoining piece. A set-screw is inserted through the nearest face of the piece. The dog-end of the set-screw enters the groove and prevents slackening of the nut.

Question: The ________ nut in which small pin is screwed in the piece adjoining the nut so that it touches one of the faces of the hexagonal nut which is sufficient to prevent its getting loose.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: The Penn nut in which small pin is screwed in the piece adjoining the nut so that it touches one of the faces of the hexagonal nut which is sufficient to prevent its getting loose. But it becomes an obstruction if the nut is required to be tightened further through a small angle.

Question: The nuts which are widely used in automobile and locomotive engines and also in steam engine are _________ nuts.
Options: d) Sawn nut or wiles nut
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Castle nut is a nut in which slots are cut in a cylindrical collar provided on the top of the nut, thus overcoming the disadvantage of the slotted nut the nuts which are widely used in automobile and locomotive engines and also in steam engine.

Question: Which of the following is not the method to prevent rotation of a bolt while screwing a nut on or off it?
Options: a) By keeping a square neck
c) By keeping a lock nut
d) By inserting a pin in shank
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The connected parts might get loose, and lead to serious breakdown a lock nut in some way so as to prevent it from getting loose but not to prevent rotation of a bolt while screwing a nut on or off.

Question: Which bolt is commonly used in bearing for shafts?
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: Square-headed bolt is commonly used in bearing for shafts and this bolt head is chamfered at its upper end. The hook bolt is used when it is not possible to drill a hole in the piece adjoining the bolt-head.

Question: Which bolt is commonly used in big ends of connecting rods, eccentrics?
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: This bolt is used when the space for accommodating the bolt-head is comparatively limited, or where the use of a spanner for holding it is to be avoided. It is commonly used in big ends of connecting rods etc.

Question: Which bolt is used in machine-tool tables in which T-slots are cut to accommodate the T-heads?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation:  This bolt is used in machine-tool tables in which T-slots are cut to accommodate the T-heads. This is often made use of in gland and stuffing box arrangement in boiler mountings such as stop valve, feed-check valve etc.

Question: The bolt which is used where the head of a bolt must not project above the surface of the connected piece is ____________
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: Countersunk-headed bolt is used where the head of a bolt must not project above the surface of the connected piece; this form of the bolt is used. It may be provided with a snug or a neck square cross-section.

Question: The bolt which is used when it is not possible to drill a hole in the piece adjoining the bolt-head is ____________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: This bolt passes through a hole in one piece only, while the other piece is gripped by the hook-shaped bolt-head. It is used when it is possible to drill a hole in the piece adjoining the bolt-head. The square neck prevents rotation of the bolt.

Question: The bolt which has a circular ring of rectangular cross-section as its head, which can be conveniently held to prevent its rotation is _______
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Eye-bolt has a circular ring of rectangular cross-section as its head, which can be conveniently held to prevent its rotation. The hook bolt is used when it is not possible to drill a hole in the piece adjoining the bolt-head.

Question: Which bolt is used as an appliance for lifting heavy machines?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Lifting eye-bolt is used as an appliance for lifting heavy machines. It is screwed inside a threaded hole on the top of the machine, directly above its centre of gravity. The hook bolt is used when it is not possible to drill a hole in the piece adjoining the bolt-head.

Question: Which bolt is mainly used in marine shaft couplings?
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Headless tapered bolt has no head and has a shank which is tapered is mainly used in marine shaft couplings. Lifting eye-bolt is used as an appliance for lifting heavy machines. Tap-bolt or cap screw is used as a screw that is when it is not possible to accommodate the nut.

Question: Which bolt is used as a screw that is when it is not possible to accommodate the nut?
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: This bolt is used as a screw that is when it is not possible to accommodate the nut. It is used as a screw that is screwed into a threaded hole in a casting instead of a nut. Frequent insertion or removal of the tap-bolt is likely to damage the threads in the casting.

Question: Bolt which consists of only a cylindrical shank threaded at both ends is called _________
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Bolt which consists of only a cylindrical shank threaded at both ends is called Stud-bolt or Stud. And some having collared are called collar studs and stud with middle portion made square in section facilitates gripping of the stud while screwing or unscrewing it.

Question: The _____________ bolt is often made use of in gland and stuffing box arrangement in boiler mountings such as stop valve, feed-check valve etc.
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation:  This bolt is used in machine-tool tables in which T-slots are cut to accommodate the T-heads. This is often made use of in gland and stuffing box arrangement in boiler mountings such as stop valve, feed-check valve etc.

Question: What type of failure will occur when rivets are smaller than necessary?
Options: a) Tearing of plate between the holes
b) Tearing of plate between the edges
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: Shearing of the rivet takes place if the diameter of the rivet is smaller than necessary. Tearing of the plate between the edges of the plate and rivet-hole takes place if the hole is too near the edge.

Question: The necessary diameter (d) for thickness of plates (t) is ______
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: To prevent failure, the joint should be carefully designed. For elementary work, suitable values of the rivet diameter, positions of holes etc. for a given thickness of the plates the given empirical formulae is used.

Question: The thickness of the fullering tool is about the ___________ as that of the plates.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: To prevent leakage through the joint, the plates are firmly formed together by caulking or fullering processes. Both the processes are generally performed with the aid of pneumatic power. The thickness of the fullering tool is about the same as that of the plates.

Question: Tearing of the plate between the holes is taken when ________________________
Options: a) they are near to each other
b) the hole is too near the edge
c) diameter of rivet is too small
d) rivet and plate is of different metals
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Tearing of the plate between the holes takes place if they are very near to each other. Tearing of the plate between the edges of the plate and rivet-hole takes place if the hole is too near the edge.

Question: Tearing of the plate between the edges of the plate and rivet-hole takes place when ____________
Options: a) they are near to each other
b) the hole is too near the edge
c) diameter of rivet is too small
d) rivet and plate is of different metals
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Tearing of the plate between the edges of the plate and rivet-hole takes place if the hole is too near the edge. Tearing of the plate between the holes takes place if they are very near to each other.

Question: Width (L) of overlap of sheets is equal to ________ when d is the diameter of a rivet in case of single-riveted lap joint.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: For a lap joint, if the plates are made to connect using only one row of rivets then it is called single-riveted lap joint. A joint is said to be double-riveted, triple riveted etc. accordingly to the number of rows of rivets in it.

Question: In zigzag lap joint formation when P is the pitch between the rivets, the distance between the rows of rivets should not be less than _____
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: For a lap joint, if the plates are made to connect using only one row of rivets then it is called single-riveted lap joint. A joint is said to be double-riveted, triple riveted etc. accordingly to the number of rows of rivets in it.

Question: In butt joint when one strap is used the thickness varies between _______ to ________ (T is the thickness of plate to be connected).
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: For a lap joint, if the plates are made to connect using only one row of rivets then it is called single-riveted lap joint. The width of overlap L is equal to 3d when d is the diameter of rivet.

Question: In butt joint when two straps are used the thickness varies between _______ to ________ (T is the thickness of plate to be connected).
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: When two or more rows of rivets are required, rivets may be arranged in chain or zigzag formations. In chain formation the rivets are arranged directly opposite to each other but in zigzag they are staggered.

Question: The flat ends of a boiler are prevented from bulging out and are strengthened by means of _________
Options: a) connection of plates at right angles
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: In a butt joint, edges of the plates to be connected are butted against each other and the joint between them is covered by butt-plates or butt-straps on one or both sides. At least two rows of rivets, one in each connected plate, are necessary to make the joint.

Question: In _________ welding heavy current (50,000A) is passed through the joint which gets melt and welding is under external pressure.
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: When welding of two metal parts are carried out by heating the parts at joint up to plastic condition and then joined together by applying external mechanical pressure it is named as Pressure welding or forge welding.

Question: In which of the following welding only fusion welding takes place?
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: In this welding heavy current (50,000A) is passed through the joint which gets melt. The welding is completely under external pressure. Spot welding, seam welding and flash butt welding are examples of pressure resistance welding.

Question: The commands Erase, Copy, Mirror, Trim, Extend, Break etc belongs to which tool bar?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The commands Erase, Copy, Mirror, Trim, Extend, Break, Join, Scale, Array etc belongs to ‘Modify tool bar’. The commands Donut, Block, Spline, Hatch, Rectangle, Ellipse, Polygon, and Arc etc belong to ‘Draw tool bar’.

Question: The commands Donut, Block, Spline, Polygon, and Arc etc belong to which tool bar?
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: The commands Erase, Copy, Mirror, Trim, Extend, Break, Join, Scale, Array etc belongs to ‘Modify tool bar’. The commands Donut, Block, Spline, Hatch, Rectangle, Ellipse, Polygon, and Arc etc belong to ‘Draw tool bar’.

Question: The command which works on two lines or a single poly line to create a beveled edge is __________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: Chamfer works on two lines or a single poly line to create a beveled edge. Fillet is used to create a round corner between two lines. Stretch command can either lengthen entities or shorten them and thus their shapes.

Question: The command which is used to create a round corner between two lines is __________
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: Fillet is used to create a round corner between two lines. Chamfer works on two lines or a single poly line to create a beveled edge. Stretch command can either lengthen entities or shorten them and thus their shapes.

Question: The command ‘Oops’ is used to ______________
Options: a) create one or more copies of selected objects at another location
b) creates mirror image of selected objects about specified line
c) retrieves all objects erased by the last erase
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The command ‘Oops’ is used to retrieves all objects erased by the last erase. Mirror is used to creates mirror image of selected objects about specified line. Command copy creates one or more copies of selected objects at another location.

Question: The command ‘pedit’ is used for _______________
Options: a) erases a portion of line, arc, circle or a 2D poly line between two selected points
b) reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands
c) breaking a poly line into individual segments
d) editing of poly line properties
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: The command ‘pedit’ is used for editing of poly line properties. Command ‘U’ is used for reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands. Command ‘break’ is used for erases a portion of line, arc, circle or a 2D poly line between two selected points.

Question: The command ‘break’ is used for ____________________
Options: a) erases a portion of line, arc, circle or a 2D poly line between two selected points
b) reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands
c) breaking a poly line into individual segments
d) editing of poly line properties
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: The command ‘break’ is used for erases a portion of line, arc, circle or a 2D poly line between two selected points. Command ‘pedit’ is used for editing of poly line properties. Command ‘U’ is used for reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands.

Question: The command ‘U’ is used for _____________________
Options: a) erases a portion of line, arc, circle or a 2D poly line between two selected points
b) reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands
c) breaking a poly line into individual segments
d) editing of poly line properties
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: The command ‘U’ is used for reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands. Command ‘pedit’ is used for editing of poly line properties. Command ‘break’ is used for erases a portion of line, arc, circle or a 2D poly line between two selected points.

Question: The command ‘Explode’ is used for _________________________
Options: a) erases a portion of line, arc, circle or a 2D poly line between two selected points
b) reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands
c) breaking a poly line into individual segments
d) editing of poly line properties
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: The command ‘Explode’ is used for breaking a poly line into individual segments. Command ‘pedit’ is used for editing of poly line properties. Command ‘U’ is used for reverses the effects of a series of previously used commands.

Question: The command which is used to set a new coordinate system by shifting the working XY plane to be the desired location is?
Answer:
Answer: c
Explanation: UCS is used to set a new coordinate system by shifting the working XY plane to be desired location. 3DFACE is used for making planar unmeshed surfaces that have three or four sides. VPOINT is used to set the viewpoint in 3D space for viewing the 3D models.

Question: The command which is used for making planar unmeshed surfaces that have three or four sides is ______________
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: 3DFACE is used for making planar unmeshed surfaces that have three or four sides. VPOINT is used to set the viewpoint in 3D space for viewing the 3D models. UCS is used to set a new coordinate system by shifting the working XY plane to be the desired location.

Question: The command which is used to set the viewpoint in 3D space for viewing the 3D models is _____________
Answer:
Answer: b
Explanation: VPOINT is used to set the viewpoint in 3D space for viewing the 3D models. 3DFACE is used for making planar unmeshed surfaces that have three or four sides. UCS is used to set a new coordinate system by shifting the working XY plane to be the desired location.

Question: The command which is used to set elevation and thickness properties for 2D wireframe objects such as line, point, circle, polygon, arc is ____________
Answer:
Answer: d
Explanation: ELEV is used to set elevation and thickness properties for 2D wireframe objects such as line, point, circle, polygon and arc. 3DFACE is used for making planar unmeshed surfaces that have three or four sides.

Question: The command which identifies the points on drawing entities that are visible on screen is ________ and this option allows the user to pick-up the points very accurately with respect to drawing displayed.
Answer:
Answer: a
Explanation: The command which identifies the points on drawing entities that are visible on screen is OSNAP. This option allows the user to pick-up the points very accurately with respect to drawing displayed.
